This is pretty cool! Though, one thing, it might be more water-tight if you put the hot glue on the inside of the holes instead/also. Since the pressure of the water pushes outward on the container, if the hot glue is on the outside then it can easily pop it off of the side. Conversely, if the hot glue is inside, the water simply pushes it more tightly onto the hole.

Please let me know if I'm wrong, but this would seem logical to me.

The ratio of easy to find things vs things you would find in an electronics supply store baffles me.  Why would you use the keychain when you could get an LED and some batteries at the same place you would have got the switches?  The end product looks cool, but the way you got there is a little clunky.  You could have tied the light into the motor easily and bypassed the batteries.  And why did you attach the wires for the light at an apex instead of in a straight line like you did the motor wires?  Overall, this is the most confusing build you have done.  However, thank you for continuing to produce content to get people thinking about how to make cool things around the house.

A even better method for splicing cord. Because it is multi-stranded wire you can for the stripped strands in to each other. Add heat shrink first force ends together so the strands for lack of a better word braid them selves together solder and shrink the heat shrink. Oh meant to add add a larger heat shrink tube that goes over the entire cord both wires as well and you will get very clean joint. The solder will work its way between the strands and hold every thing much stronger than it was even before you cut and made the splice. It will be the strongest point in the cord

Next time you do a wire splice like that,
stagger the ends. One of the wires on
that "lamp cord" will be marked.
Cut an inch off of one wire of the
short length, and cut an inch off the
different wire on the long piece.

Now do your splice. the splices should
NOT line up with each other. That is what
you want.

Pro tip. Offset your wire lengths when you cut them. This will help in making sure the cut areas are not laying next to each other and will help the finished wire to lay flatter without a bulge where all the slices and shrink tubeing are bunched up. Also forget the electrical tape. Use a larger diameter shrink tube to hold the separate wies together. Much cleaner.
